stream_context.summary: Kaze showcased progress on an ice castle level, discussing platforming design and visual polish. The main focus was a deep technical collaboration with guest Sauraen to integrate and debug F3DX3, a new N64 microcode, to significantly improve the game's performance, particularly in RSP-bound scenes.

development_findings.summary: A public demo of the game is planned for release in a 'few more weeks'.

Kaze is officially adopting F3DX3, a new, custom N64 microcode by Sauraen, to achieve significant performance gains that were previously unattainable, moving the game's bottleneck from the RDP to the RSP.
development_findings.quote: We might be able to get around 300 microseconds of performance in X1 for free. And then a lot more performance globally in the entire game for free.

development_findings.summary: The platforming gameplay for the ice castle level (Course 13) is complete, with current work focused on visual polish and texturing.
A key gameplay setpiece in the ice castle will be a mirror that Mario can wallkick off of, creating a unique visual and mechanical challenge.
development_findings.quote: Right here, this will be a mirror. And there will be a wallkick section. On the mirror. So it will look like you're punching wallkick mirror Mario.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is designing difficult sections with fairness in mind, explicitly adding coin paths and platforms to allow players to recover from mistakes.
A visual effect where objects fade into view is achieved through a multi-texture technique combining a dither pattern with alpha manipulation on vertices.

The team is navigating complex optimization trade-offs between different methods like Fast64's 'map bleeding', F3DX3's 'auto-batching', and Ocarina of Time's armature rendering style to handle animated models efficiently.
development_findings.quote: The way OOT does it is there is no... Okay, so for skinned meshes, which means you have triangles that go across different bones, which is normally how it is. There is a region of memory that is allocated that has all of the matrices for all of the limbs.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to implement emulator-specific code paths, particularly for lighting, to ensure the game works on emulators while using the advanced F3DX3 features on original hardware.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes his project has pushed past the N64's commonly understood RDP (graphics) bottleneck and is now facing an RSP (co-processor) bottleneck, requiring new, deeper levels of optimization.
context_findings.quote: It's interesting to note that for like the last 28 years I was like well the reason the n64 is slow is because of fill rate and memory throughput and now we're at this point and actually it's the rsp.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds strong, critical opinions on the technical implementations of revered N64 games, believing Rare's optimization work on Banjo-Kazooie is poor and that their developers were 'snobby' about design principles they didn't adhere to.
context_findings.quote: I'm about to fail a fucking QuickTime event and go on a full rant about how terrible Banjo-Kazooie optimizes.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong dislike for the passive, turn-based combat of JRPGs like Final Fantasy VII, which informs his own design preference for active, continuous player engagement.
context_findings.quote: Goddamn, I hate JRPGs. I'm playing the Switch version where you have the free time speed modifier and still, literally 50% of the gameplay time is just me sitting there like this. Just attack.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, are new parents. He mentions their baby is with grandparents during the stream, indicating a balance between family life and development work.
Kaze is aware of and connected to the broader N64 decompilation community, citing recent work by Vaisky on the Banjo-Kazooie decompilation project.

biobak.summary: Biobak was present in the chat and offered praise for the visual quality of Kaze's level design, stating it 'looks insane'.
biobak.quote: I think the levels you're making are a lot prettier.

badub.summary: No new findings about Badub were mentioned in this stream.

zeina.summary: Zeina is actively creating assets for the game; Kaze mentioned she is currently working on assets for an upcoming outdoor area described as a 'little village with penguin huts'.

key_stories.title: The F3DX3 Performance Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Kaze's game was hitting a performance wall due to an RSP bottleneck. He collaborated live with Sauraen to integrate F3DX3, a new N64 microcode. After a deep technical dive, they achieved a significant performance breakthrough, fixing a major framerate drop and unlocking more potential for the game.
key_stories.challenge: A key scene with many animated models was causing the framerate to drop below 30 FPS. The game was bottlenecked by the RSP (co-processor), a problem that standard optimizations couldn't solve.
key_stories.process: Kaze collaborated live with Sauraen, the creator of F3DX3. Sauraen explained the microcode's features, including a larger vertex buffer and auto-batched rendering. They benchmarked performance, debugged compatibility issues, and quantified the gains, which were substantial.
key_stories.outcome: The integration of F3DX3 was a success, boosting the framerate in the problematic scene to a stable 30 FPS. Kaze officially committed to using F3DX3 for the project, gaining significant performance headroom and access to future optimizations like occlusion planes.
key_stories.key_quote: It's interesting to note that for like the last 28 years I was like well the reason the n64 is slow is because of fill rate and memory throughput and now we're at this point and actually it's the rsp.

key_stories.title: The Corrupted Profiler Text
key_stories.summary: While integrating a new microcode, the profiler's text became corrupted. Kaze and Sauraen debugged the issue live, initially suspecting a deep technical bug. The culprit was ultimately a simple, forgotten piece of 'rainbow text' code Kaze had copied, demonstrating the collaborative and sometimes messy reality of community-driven development.
key_stories.challenge: The on-screen performance profiler displayed corrupted text when using the new F3DX3 microcode, making it impossible to accurately measure performance gains.
key_stories.process: Kaze and Sauraen initially suspected a complex microcode or GBI (graphics binary interface) bug. After their initial theories failed, they examined the C code for text rendering and Sauraen spotted a suspicious second texture load operation within the function.
key_stories.outcome: The bug was traced to a block of old, unused code for a 'rainbow text' effect that Kaze had copied from a shared repository. Removing the dead code instantly fixed the text rendering, highlighting the sometimes-unpredictable nature of building on shared community projects.
key_stories.key_quote: I copied this from your repo. I yes you did and uh, I am not the only person who works on that repo. So well then fix the entire issue.

key_stories.title: The Unoptimized Bunnies
key_stories.summary: A poorly optimized rabbit model was causing major performance issues. The team debated the best fix: manual restructuring, Fast64's 'map bleeding', or relying on F3DX3's new 'auto-batching'. The incident became a case study in the complex trade-offs of modern N64 development and the power of new tools to solve old problems.
key_stories.challenge: A scene with multiple animated rabbit models was inefficiently structured, reloading the same material 14 times per model and causing a 3-millisecond performance hit from texture loads alone.
key_stories.process: Sauraen explained that his F3DX3 microcode's auto-batching could mitigate the issue. This sparked a discussion with Lilaa (a Fast64 dev) about alternative solutions like 'map bleeding'. They concluded that for this specific case, F3DX3's feature was superior, and the best long-term fix was manual asset restructuring.
key_stories.outcome: F3DX3's auto-batching feature provided an immediate 3ms performance gain by automatically skipping the redundant loads. While Kaze still plans to fix the asset manually, the incident powerfully demonstrated the new microcode's ability to solve common performance problems that were previously difficult to manage.
key_stories.key_quote: Leave your bunnies unoptimized and let F3DX3 save you. That's the right approach here.

open_questions.topic: Kaze's Relationship with Rare's N64 Legacy
open_questions.context: Kaze went on a detailed rant about what he perceives as poor optimization in Banjo-Kazooie and snobbery from the developers of Conker's Bad Fur Day.
questions: You seem to have strong feelings about Rare's development practices on the N64. How has their work influenced you, both in what to do and what not to do?
Do you feel there's a mythos around Rare as 'N64 gods' that doesn't hold up to technical scrutiny?
How does this perspective shape your own goals for technical excellence in your projects?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that Zeina is currently creating assets for an upcoming 'penguin village' area.
questions: Kaze mentioned you're working on assets for the penguin village. Could you walk us through your creative process for that?
How do you and Kaze collaborate on the art style? Do you work from a brief, or is it more of a back-and-forth conversation?
What's it like balancing your professional collaboration on the game with your personal relationship as spouses?

open_questions.context: Sauraen gave a deep technical overview of F3DX3, explaining how he rewrote vertex processing and added features like auto-batching. He mentioned its philosophy evolved from adding graphical effects to maximizing performance.
questions: Sauraen, what was the initial spark that made you decide the N64 needed a new microcode like F3DX3?
You talked about the 'philosophy' of X3. How has that philosophy evolved from when you started to now, working with developers like Kaze?
What does it mean to you to be creating fundamental new technology for a nearly 30-year-old console? What's the ultimate goal?

open_questions.context: The stream was a live collaboration between Kaze (using the SM64 decomp), Sauraen (creating a new microcode), and Lilaa from the Fast64 team (contributing from chat).
questions: How would you describe the relationship between the SM64 decompilation project, tools like Fast64, and new tech like F3DX3?
How important is this open, collaborative community to making a project like Return to Yoshi's Island possible?
Can you talk about the dynamic of building on each other's work, like when you discovered the 'rainbow text' bug from a shared repo?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned a demo is coming in 'a few more weeks' and that his editor has been working on a video.
questions: What are your goals for the upcoming demo? Is it for player feedback, building hype, or something else?
What content will be included in the demo?
How does releasing a demo fit into your overall strategy for the project's development and eventual release?
